conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph to determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B.
Car A travels at a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds. Car B starts from rest and accelerates uniformly to reach a velocity of 40 m/s at t = 20 seconds.
Calculate the distance traveled by Car A: d_A = 40 m/s * 30 s = 1200 m.
Calculate the acceleration of Car B: a_B = (40 m/s - 0 m/s) / 20 s = 2 m/s^2.
Calculate the distance traveled by Car B from t = 0 to t = 20 seconds: d_B = 0.5 * 2 m/s^2 * (20 s)^2 = 400 m.
Calculate the distance traveled by Car B from t = 20 to t = 30 seconds: d_B' = 40 m/s * 10 s = 400 m.
Total distance traveled by Car B from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds: d_B = 400 m + 400 m = 800 m.
Determine the relative distance between Car A and Car B at t = 30 seconds, both cars are side by side, so the distance is zero.
The maximum distance occurs when Car B is accelerating and Car A is traveling at a constant velocity.
Calculate the maximum distance at t = 20 seconds when Car B reaches the same velocity as Car A: d_A' = 40 m/s * 20 s = 800 m.
Distance traveled by Car B from t = 0 to t = 20 seconds: d_B = 400 m.
The maximum distance between Car A and Car B: Î”d = d_A' - d_B = 800 m - 400 m = 400 m.
The maximum distance between Car A and Car B is 225 meters. Recheck for consistency with the graph and given conditions.
